Legal_Issue: Whether the Royal Bank sufficiently used the trademark 'Informaction' to avoid expungement under s. 45 of the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: Vague evidence of reintroduction of the trademark; internal use not considered use in the normal course of trade
Burden_of_Proof: On the Royal Bank to demonstrate use or special circumstances for nonuse
Credibility_Factor: Lack of credible, concrete evidence showing public or commercial use of the trademark
Legal_Rule: A trademark must be used in the normal course of trade to distinguish wares or services; nonuse may be excused only by special circumstances
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, considering Registrar's decision and new evidence
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of expungement due to nonuse of trademark from 1986 to 1991
Outcome_on_Merits: Royal Bank failed to prove sufficient use or special circumstances
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature and extent of trademark use; timing of discontinuation and reintroduction; internal vs. commercial use
Defendant_Response: Royal Bank claimed continued use or justification for nonuse, but evidence was insufficient
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of trademark usage, operational records
Outcome: Trademark expunged; appeal dismissed with costs

Legal_Issue: Whether the trademark CAMBRIDGE was 'in use in Canada' under s. 44(1) of the Trade Marks Act
Governing_Law: Trade Marks Act, s. 4 and s. 44(1)
Evidence_Assessment: Additional affidavits considered, but not as a trial de novo
Burden_of_Proof: Registrant (Imperial Tobacco) must prove use or special circumstances for non-use
Credibility_Factor: Affidavits and invoices deemed sufficient to establish genuine commercial transactions
Legal_Rule: A trademark is 'in use' if marked on wares or packaging during normal commercial transactions (s. 4)
Standard_of_Review: Assessment of evidence for sufficiency to prove use in the normal course of trade
Grounds_for_Claim: Philip Morris claimed insufficient evidence of use by Imperial Tobacco
Outcome_on_Merits: Trademark CAMBRIDGE was found to be in use in Canada
Key_Evidence_Considered: Invoices, affidavits, and records of continuous sales of CAMBRIDGE cigarettes
Defendant_Response: Imperial Tobacco provided evidence of continuous commercial use
Remedy_Requested: Cancellation of trademark registration based on non-use
Legal_Provision: s. 44(1) and s. 4 of the Trade Marks Act

Legal_Issue: Whether the trademark 'EXISTENCE' was in use in Canada as required by s. 44 of the Trade Marks Act?
Evidence_Assessment: Single bona fide sale of four jars of face cream; advertising evidence; bankruptcy of distributor considered but not proven sufficient to excuse nonuse
Burden_of_Proof: Appellant proved sufficient use under s. 44
Credibility_Factor: Bona fide sale and advertising; lack of proof regarding distributor's bankruptcy impact
Legal_Rule: Under s. 44, a trademark must be in use in Canada or have special circumstances excusing nonuse to avoid expungement
Standard_of_Review: Court reviewed use and special circumstances
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged nonuse of the trademark 'EXISTENCE'
Key_Evidence_Considered: Sale of four jars of face cream; advertising materials
Defendant_Response: Charme et Beauté Lise Watier Inc. requested expungement due to alleged nonuse
Legal_Provision: s. 44 of the Trade Marks Act

Legal_Issue: Likelihood of confusion between trademarks
Governing_Law: Section 6(5) of the Trade Marks Act
Procedural_Stage: Appeal after initial rejection by Opposition Board
Evidence_Assessment: Similarities in appearance, sound, and usage context; common use of 'NUTRI'; overlapping product types and markets
Burden_of_Proof: Appellant failed to prove no reasonable probability of confusion
Credibility_Factor: Additional evidence presented on appeal deemed insufficient
Legal_Rule: Factors under Section 6(5) include inherent distinctiveness, length of use, nature of wares, trade channels, and resemblance
Grounds_for_Claim: Opposition by Maximum Nutrition Limited due to potential confusion with NUTRI-MAX
Outcome_on_Merits: No sufficient proof of absence of confusion; registration opposed successfully
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of trademarks (NUTRI-BRAN, NUTRI-VITE vs NUTRI-MAX), product overlap, market similarity
Evidence_Type: Trademark usage evidence, product descriptions, market data
Outcome: Appeals dismissed; costs awarded to respondent
Legal_Provision: Section 6(5) of the Trade Marks Act

Legal_Issue: Whether the Registrar erred in maintaining the 'Jamesway' trademark registration due to alleged non-use
Evidence_Assessment: Evaluation of invoices and affidavits regarding use of the trademark
Decision_Outcome: Registrar's decision to maintain registration upheld
Burden_of_Proof: On trademark owner to show use or special circumstances for non-use
Credibility_Factor: Affidavits and documentary evidence (invoices) submitted by both parties
Legal_Rule: Section 45 requires evidence of use or special circumstances excusing non-use
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied to Registrar's decision
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged non-use of the trademark 'Jamesway' over time
Key_Evidence_Considered: Invoices showing use, explanation of corporate reorganization
Legal_Framework: Trade-marks Act, Canadian intellectual property law
Defendant_Response: Reorganization justified non-use; provided evidence of use via invoices

Legal_Issue: Whether the absence of use of the trademark CFP by IBCFP in Canada can be excused due to special circumstances
Evidence_Assessment: New evidence showing continuous use by the College and special circumstances
Decision_Outcome: Appeal allowed; absence of use excused due to special circumstances
Burden_of_Proof: IBCFP to demonstrate special circumstances excusing non-use
Credibility_Factor: Inadvertent failure to appoint the College as a registered user
Legal_Rule: Section 44(3) allows expungement unless special circumstances excuse non-use
Grounds_for_Claim: Non-use of trademark in Canada
Key_Evidence_Considered: Continuous use by the College, intent to maintain use, inadvertent administrative omission
Defendant_Response: Argued special circumstances due to inadvertent failure to appoint College as registered user
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, intent evidence, usage records

Legal_Issue: Whether failure to use the trademark 'Fascination' for three years constitutes special circumstances excusing non-use under s. 45 of the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: Appellant provided no evidence of when use would resume or specific obstacles preventing use; recession deemed a common situation, not special circumstances
Burden_of_Proof: On appellant to prove special circumstances justifying non-use
Credibility_Factor: Lack of credible evidence from appellant regarding future use or external obstacles
Legal_Rule: Under s. 45(3), a trademark may be expunged if not in use and absence of use is not due to special circumstances beyond the owner's control
Standard_of_Review: Statutory interpretation and application of s. 45 of the Trade-marks Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Non-use of trademark for over three years without justification by special circumstances
Outcome_on_Merits: Appellant failed to meet burden; claim rejected
Key_Evidence_Considered: Economic conditions cited as reason for non-use; lack of evidence on timing of resumption or specific impediments
Legal_Framework: Canadian Trade-marks Act, administrative and appellate review procedures
Defendant_Response: Economic downturn (recession) as reason for non-use
Evidence_Type: Oral/affidavit evidence on economic conditions, lack of documentary evidence on future plans
Outcome: Trademark 'Fascination' expunged; costs awarded to respondent

Legal_Issue: Whether the respondent demonstrated 'special circumstances' excusing nonuse of the trademark 'PROMODE' under s. 45 of the Trade Marks Act
Procedural_Stage: Appeal under s. 56 of the Trade Marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: Delays due to organizational challenges, industry cycles, key personnel resignations, and deliberate business planning were assessed as valid
Burden_of_Proof: Respondent bore the burden to show special circumstances for nonuse
Credibility_Factor: Senior Hearing Officer found respondent's evidence credible and sufficient
Legal_Rule: Under s. 45, nonuse of a trademark may lead to expungement unless excused by special circumstances
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied to Registrar's decision
Grounds_for_Claim: Appellants claimed nonuse of 'PROMODE' without justification
Key_Evidence_Considered: Organizational delays, industry cycles, resignation of key personnel, strategic business planning
Defendant_Response: Respondent argued special circumstances justified nonuse
Evidence_Type: Documentary and factual evidence of business operations and challenges
Outcome: Appeal dismissed with costs; registration upheld
Legal_Provision: s. 45 and s. 56 of the Trade Marks Act
Authority: Senior Hearing Officer, Registrar of Trademarks

Legal_Issue: Whether Konica's use of the plaintiff's trademarks in promotional packaging constitutes trademark infringement
Evidence_Assessment: Visibility of plaintiff's trademarks on the Guinness Book of Olympic Records packaging used as a premium with Konica film
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff demonstrated a serious issue to be tried and risk of irreparable harm
Credibility_Factor: Likelihood of consumer confusion or implied association due to trademark visibility
Legal_Rule: Unauthorized use of registered trademarks in connection with wares or services violates Sections 9 and 11 of the Trade Marks Act
Standard_of_Review: Serious issue to be tried and balance of convenience favoring plaintiff
Grounds_for_Claim: Konica's packaging associated plaintiff's trademarks with its product without authorization
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided at this stage; preliminary finding of potential infringement sufficient for injunction
Key_Evidence_Considered: Packaging combining Konica film with a book cover displaying the plaintiff's trademarks
Remedy_Requested: Interlocutory injunction to halt distribution of contested packaging
Outcome: Injunction granted, Konica restrained from marketing film in the challenged package form
Legal_Provision: Sections 9 and 11 of the Trade Marks Act

Legal_Issue: Whether NTD Apparel Inc. can demonstrate special circumstances excusing non-use of the KOALA BLUE trademark
Procedural_Stage: Appeal to Federal Court under section 56 of the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: NTD did not use the trademark during the required period and provided insufficient evidence of special circumstances
Burden_of_Proof: On trademark owner (NTD Apparel Inc.) to show use or special circumstances
Credibility_Factor: Insufficient evidence of concrete steps toward resuming use or obstacles beyond control
Legal_Rule: Section 45 requires use or special circumstances excusing non-use within three years preceding notice
Grounds_for_Claim: Non-use of trademark without justification by special circumstances
Key_Evidence_Considered: Lack of trademark use; absence of documented efforts to resume use; no proof of external obstacles
Defendant_Response: Claimed special circumstances but failed to provide sufficient supporting evidence
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of use or non-use, explanations for non-use
Remedy_Requested: Retention of trademark registration based on alleged special circumstances

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged involvement with Battalion 3-16 and participation in kidnappings and torture
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act (sections 4 to 7)
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Immigration Division's finding of inadmissibility upheld
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court
Crimes.Protected_Group: Victims of kidnappings, torture, and murder
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Perceived political opponents or dissidents in Honduras during the 1980s
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Battalion 3-16 operated as part of state apparatus committing abuses
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Membership and participation in a repressive military unit
Crimes.Credibility: Prior admissions by applicant supported findings of involvement
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 4 to 7 of the Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: State protection was inadequate or complicit in abuses
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Systematic human rights violations by state agents
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Political opinion, perceived opposition to government

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Systematic and organized nature of abuses, use of state power
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Claim of duress and limited personal involvement
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: No prior criminal record noted; alleged wartime conduct
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – involvement in torture and enforced disappearances
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Serious risk to public order and international obligations
Crimes.Risk_Type: Threat to Canada’s international legal commitments
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Participation in war crimes under international law
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Targeting of individuals based on political beliefs
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient – based on admissions and documentary evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible – consistent with historical records and prior statements
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s claims of limited role not fully credible
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s.35(1)(a), Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged participation in kidnappings, torture, and murders by Battalion 3-16
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act (sections 4 to 7)
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Immigration Division's determination upheld on review
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Applicant seeking entry or stay in Canada
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Political dissidents in Honduras during the 1980s
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: State actors were perpetrators; no effective protection
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Association with a unit engaged in widespread human rights abuses
Crimes.Credibility: Applicant’s denial of significant involvement found less credible than evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 4 to 7 of the Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: State protection unavailable due to state-perpetrated violence
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Widespread and systematic attacks against civilian population
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Political opinion, identity as perceived opponent

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in a Limited Brutal Purpose Organization
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Membership in Battalion 3-16, known for kidnappings and torture
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: State institutions were instruments of abuse
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Active membership in an organization with brutal purpose
Crimes.Credibility: Evidence of membership and knowledge of activities deemed credible

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of rejection of duress defense
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in rejecting the defense of duress
Crimes.Governing_Law: Common law principles of duress applied within IRPA framework
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Immigration Division decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Board weighed applicant’s fear of death against harm caused
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish duress; not met
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant had opportunity to escape but did not
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Duress requires threat of harm greater than harm inflicted
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Applicant claimed coercion into participating in abuses
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Potential for escape, extent of victim harm, applicant’s continued participation
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed forced participation under threat of death
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Overturn of inadmissibility finding based on duress

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making untrue statements in Personal Information Form
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the Board's decision to find the applicant not credible reasonable under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Contradictions between testimony and Personal Information Form, implausible elements in story, inconsistencies in documents
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to provide credible evidence supporting claim
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Credibility findings reviewed on reasonableness standard with margin of appreciation
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution due to alleged anti-revolutionary activities
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim not well-founded due to lack of credibility
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Personal Information Form, testimony, submitted documents
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal Information Form, oral testimony, documentary evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Challenge to credibility based on document alterations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Board make an unreasonable decision in determining lack of credibility due to manual alterations?
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Altered subpoenas and inconsistent testimony reduced credibility
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Factor: Authenticity and reliability of submitted documents

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with police reporting requirements
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Conditions related to police reporting while claiming asylum
Crimes.Application_Facts: Claimant reported weekly to police while allegedly delivering anti-revolutionary videos
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Implausibility of managing both reporting and subversive activities
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturn of Board’s negative credibility finding

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim based on political persecution
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the Board's decision unreasonable in determining lack of credibility?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Contradictions in story, such as delivering videos while reporting to police
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to prove well-founded fear
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to lack of credibility
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Asylum claim involving illegal economic conduct
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Board unreasonably find the applicant lacked credibility?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Contradictions in story, including implausible activities and document inconsistencies
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to demonstrate well-founded claim
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Credibility findings subject to reasonableness review
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to lack of credible evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Risk_Assessment: Well-founded fear claimed but not established
Targeted_Victimization: No evidence of targeting based on Convention grounds
Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to establish nexus to Convention grounds
Credibility_Assessment: Not fully substantiated in legal context

Basis_for_Decision: Generalized risk, lack of Convention nexus

Prior_Criminality: Pattern of corruption and extortion by perpetrators
Targeted_Victimization: No evidence of individualized targeting beyond extortion victim

Legal_Issue: Nexus to Convention grounds
Personalized risk under IRPA
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient to prove targeted risk or Convention link
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant – not met
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's account plausible but lacks legal nexus
Legal_Rule: Well-founded fear of persecution on Convention grounds required
Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution due to resistance to corruption
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of extortion
Retaliation
Police-criminal collusion

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failing to Comply with a Probation Order

Legal_Issue: Consideration of unproven charges
Evidence_Assessment: Lacked verification
Legal_Rule: Cannot rely on withdrawn charges without credible evidence
Grounds_for_Claim: Improper consideration of unproven charges
Key_Evidence_Considered: Withdrawn kidnapping charge
Police report

Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge's decision adequately explained how the residence requirement was met
Evidence_Assessment: Contradictions in evidence regarding residency were not addressed
Decision_Outcome: Original decision set aside due to inadequate reasoning
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate compliance with residence requirements
Legal_Rule: Standard of review for adequacy of reasons is correctness; determination of residence compliance is reviewed under reasonableness standard
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for adequacy of reasons; reasonableness for residence determination
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient reasoning by citizenship judge, failure to apply clear residency test
Outcome_on_Merits: Decision referred to another judge for redetermination
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's continued residence in France since 2005 while holding permanent resident status in Canada
Legal_Framework: Canadian Citizenship Act, residency requirements for naturalization
Defendant_Response: Baron did not appear or defend the application
Evidence_Type: Residency records, application documents, judicial findings
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review sought by the Crown
Outcome: Original decision annulled, case remanded for reconsideration
Legal_Provision: Residence requirement under Canadian citizenship law

Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in administrative decision-making
Decision_Outcome: May 5, 1992 decision quashed, effects stayed pending new tribunal
Burden_of_Proof: On appellant to demonstrate procedural unfairness
Legal_Rule: Administrative decisions must adhere to procedural fairness standards, including unbiased tribunal, proper notice, and right to representation
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on context
Grounds_for_Claim: Bias, lack of proper notice, denial of right to representation
Outcome_on_Merits: Procedural unfairness found; decision set aside
Key_Evidence_Considered: Tribunal proceedings, notice documentation, participation records
Remedy_Requested: Quashing of decision, redetermination by new tribunal
Outcome: Decision quashed, stay of effect, new tribunal ordered
Authority: Cowessess Indian Band #73 Appeal Tribunal, judicial review court

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Minister's refusal under ITOA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Minister ignored relevant facts about accomplices' transfers and failed to assess future organized crime risk
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Minister must consider statutory factors and provide transparent reasons
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to consider relevant facts and inadequate reasoning
Key_Evidence_Considered: Accomplices' transfers
Lack of evidence on ongoing organized crime ties

Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Failure to provide transparent and intelligible reasons
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Convicted of conspiracy to distribute narcotics
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Potential ongoing ties to organized crime
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Assessment of future risk related to organized crime
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Inadequate assessment of organized crime risk and failure to address key facts
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International Transfer of Offenders Act and administrative law
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to address relevant evidence and provide intelligible reasoning

Legal_Issue: Is the PRRA Officer's decision regarding state protection in Honduras reasonable?
Governing_Law: Rule: State protection analysis requires assessing the operational effectiveness of a country’s protective measures, especially in countries with acknowledged institutional failings.
Evidence_Assessment: The PRRA Officer dismissed his claims due to lack of police reports, ignoring evidence of police ineffectiveness and corruption.
Decision_Outcome: The judicial review is granted, the decision is quashed and referred back for reconsideration by a different officer.
Legal_Rule: State protection analysis requires assessing the operational effectiveness of a country’s protective measures, especially in countries with acknowledged institutional failings.
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of returning to Honduras due to gang violence and inadequate state protection.
Outcome_on_Merits: Decision overturned, case remanded for new assessment.
Key_Evidence_Considered: Evidence of police ineffectiveness and corruption in Honduras.
Legal_Framework: PRRA process, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Legal_Provision: IRPA sections related to Pre-Removal Risk Assessment

Legal_Issue: Is the PRRA Officer's decision regarding state protection in Honduras reasonable?
Governing_Law: Rule: Findings of state protection must be reasonable and consider the operational effectiveness of state measures, especially in countries with acknowledged failings.
Outcome: Decision overturned, case remanded for reassessment by another officer.
Legal_Provision: IRPA sections related to Pre-Removal Risk Assessment
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of return due to inadequate state protection in Honduras
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Operational effectiveness of Honduran state protection
Application_Error: Failed to assess functionality of state protection, focused only on institutional existence
Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of corruption and gang violence undermining state protection
Application_Factor: Nature and severity of gang-related risks
Decision_Outcome: Decision quashed, referred back for new decision

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to appear for a refugee hearing
Violation_Type: Failure to appear for a scheduled refugee hearing
Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA provisions regarding attendance at refugee proceedings
Governing_Law: Rule: Decisions on state protection must reasonably assess the operational effectiveness of state measures, considering country conditions.
Application_Facts: Applicant failed to appear for refugee hearing, later returned to Canada claiming fear of gang violence.
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to failure to appear and illegal re-entry
Procedural_Issue: Failure to appear leading to dismissal and deportation
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence and applicant testimony on risk in Honduras
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer did not assess effectiveness of state protection despite available evidence
Decision_Outcome: Decision overturned due to unreasonable assessment
Relief_Sought: Reassessment of PRRA based on fear of gang violence and police retaliation
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by a different PRRA officer
Decision_Rationale: Officer unreasonably dismissed fear of police retaliation without proper analysis

Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA Officer's decision on state protection in Honduras was reasonable.
Governing_Law: Rule: State protection analysis must assess operational effectiveness of state measures, especially in countries with systemic failures.
Evidence_Assessment: Officer dismissed applicant’s fear of police retaliation without sufficient evidence or analysis.
Decision_Outcome: Judicial review granted, decision quashed and referred back for reevaluation.
Legal_Rule: State protection analysis must assess operational effectiveness of state measures, especially in countries with systemic failures.
Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution by MS-13 gang and inadequate state protection in Honduras
Outcome_on_Merits: Case remanded for new decision due to unreasonable conclusions
Key_Evidence_Considered: Risk from MS-13, history of illegal return, lack of state protection in Honduras
Remedy_Requested: Reevaluation of PRRA decision by a different officer
Legal_Provision: IRPA sections on Pre-Removal Risk Assessment

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of CRA's decision to dismiss ITPR application due to lateness
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant faced barriers such as being on leave and lack of access to resources
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unreasonableness of administrative decision
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's explanation for delay considered credible
Legal_Rule: Reasonableness standard applies; decision must be justified, transparent, and intelligible
Grounds_for_Claim: Misapplication of discretion, failure to consider individual circumstances, procedural unfairness
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim succeeded on grounds of administrative unreasonableness
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of delays, applicant's personal circumstances, non-mandatory nature of time limit
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, principles of procedural fairness, statutory interpretation
Defendant_Response: CRA strictly applied time limit without flexibility or contextual consideration
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, applicant's affidavit explaining delay
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, setting aside of CRA decision, reconsideration of application
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; CRA decision set aside; application remitted for reconsideration
Legal_Provision: Time limits under ITPR program (non-mandatory), Federal Courts Act provisions

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of immigration officer's decision on H&C application
Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of establishment in Canada and hardship in the Philippines
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; officer's decision upheld
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unusual or disproportionate hardship
Credibility_Factor: Officer found insufficient evidence of hardship despite HIV status and discrimination claims
Legal_Rule: H&C exemptions available under IRPA for unusual or disproportionate hardship
Grounds_for_Claim: Medical inadmissibility due to HIV, risk of disrupted treatment and discrimination in home country
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed; officer's assessment found reasonable
Key_Evidence_Considered: Establishment in Canada, access to HIV treatment, potential discrimination in the Philippines
Legal_Framework: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds provisions under IRPA
Defendant_Response: Immigration officer denied application citing insufficient hardship evidence
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of residence, health records, country condition reports
Remedy_Requested: Permanent residence in Canada on H&C grounds
Legal_Provision: Section of IRPA allowing H&C considerations

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness, reasonableness of decision, adequacy of reasons
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.40(1)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies in employment claims verified during site visits
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unfairness or unreasonableness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's explanations found implausible by officer
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Misrepresentation must be material and could induce administrative error
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged misrepresentation based on inconsistent employment details
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Site visit findings, GCMS notes, applicant responses

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness and procedural fairness of misrepresentation finding
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.40(1)
Crimes.Outcome: Applicant found inadmissible, judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims contradicted by employee statements
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Employment records, third-party statements, application documents
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: False employment status claimed by applicant
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Numerous inconsistencies between claims and verified facts
Crimes.Application_Error: Material misrepresentation that could induce administrative error
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Objective assessment of whether misrepresentation occurred
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None noted – all relevant evidence considered
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation under IRPA does not require intent
Crimes.Application_Factor: Inconsistencies in employment details raised suspicion
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Not explicitly alleged, but false information submitted

Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Colistro was constructively dismissed by the Bank
Evidence_Assessment: Adjudicator reviewed disciplinary actions, workplace incidents, and resignation circumstances; court found no evidence of bias or factual error sufficient to overturn decision
Decision_Outcome: Adjudicator's decision upheld; constructive dismissal not established
Burden_of_Proof: On Mr. Colistro to prove constructive dismissal
Credibility_Factor: Adjudicator assessed credibility of Mr. Colistro's claims and employer's conduct
Legal_Rule: Constructive dismissal occurs when employer's actions force an employee to resign
Grounds_for_Claim: Disciplinary notices, workplace conflicts, alleged constructive dismissal
Key_Evidence_Considered: Disciplinary actions, workplace incidents, voluntary resignation
Legal_Framework: Federal employment law, administrative law principles
Defendant_Response: Bank maintained that Mr. Colistro resigned voluntarily and was not constructively dismissed
Remedy_Requested: Recognition of constructive dismissal, potential compensation
Outcome: Application dismissed, adjudicator's decision affirmed, costs awarded to respondent

Dispute_Type: Appeal for extension of time and leave to appeal under pension legislation
Legal_Issue: Whether the designated member erred in granting an extension of time without applying correct legal criteria
Evidence_Assessment: Mr. Roy provided insufficient evidence of continuing intention, no new facts or medical information, no explanation for delay
Decision_Outcome: Board’s decision set aside; matter remitted for redetermination
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant (Mr. Roy) failed to meet burden for discretionary relief
Credibility_Factor: Lack of credible explanation for 18-month delay
Legal_Rule: Discretion must be exercised based on: continuing intention, arguable case, reasonable explanation for delay, and no prejudice
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with potential for correctness on questions of law
Grounds_for_Claim: Error in law, failure to apply proper legal criteria, disregard of material facts
Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of application, absence of new evidence, lack of justification for delay
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, statutory interpretation, principles of procedural fairness
Defendant_Response: Not applicable – Minister was applicant in judicial review
Remedy_Requested: Setting aside of Board’s decision and remittal for reconsideration

Legal_Issue: Does retrospective tax legislation violate Charter or Canadian Bill of Rights?
Governing_Law: Constitution Act, 1982 (s. 7 Charter), Canadian Bill of Rights (s. 1(a))
Procedural_Stage: Appeal as trial de novo in Federal Court
Evidence_Assessment: Plaintiff purchased annuity after budget announcement; claimed deduction despite knowledge of change
Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to demonstrate violation of rights
Credibility_Factor: Plaintiff was aware of the legislative change prior to purchase
Legal_Rule: Parliament may enact clear retrospective tax laws; no s. 7 or s. 1(a) infringement unless severe impact on security of person
Grounds_for_Claim: Retrospective application of tax law violates fundamental rights
Outcome_on_Merits: No violation found; law applied within legal limits
Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of annuity purchase relative to budget announcement
Clarity of legislative language
Defendant_Response: Retrospective law validly enacted and properly applied
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of transaction and budget documents
Outcome: Plaintiff must pay assessed taxes without deduction
Legal_Provision: Income Tax Act provisions on deductions, retroactive amendments

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Exclusion under Article 1F(b) of the UN Refugee Convention
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: CRDD found Mr. Liang's story implausible
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Implausibility of claim and preference for Minister's version
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of fraudulent documents to enter Canada

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Knowledge and intent in possession of false documents
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: CRDD did not explicitly assess intent
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of fraudulent passport to enter Canada

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Flight risk and danger to public
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Considered sufficient for exclusion under Article 1F(b)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Liang’s claims deemed less credible

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee exclusion based on criminal involvement
Crimes.Mode_of_Entry: Through investor program with fraudulent passport
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Serious reasons for considering criminal involvement

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee exclusion based on leadership role

Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Expert testimony on forgery given little weight
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On Minister to show serious reasons
Key_Evidence_Considered: Chinese legal documents
Expert opinion

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee exclusion due to corruption charges
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Liang fled China; state action deemed legitimate

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the risk was generalized or personalized and adequacy of state protection
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 97(1)
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: National documentation on gang violence in El Salvador; lack of reporting to authorities
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to show particularized risk and lack of state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Failure to report incidents to authorities undermined credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Refugee status requires a particularized risk not shared by the general population
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Risk from Mara Salvatrucha due to perceived wealth as businesspeople
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to generalized risk and presumed state protection
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Targeting based on perceived wealth; national country conditions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicants failed to seek or exhaust state protection remedies

Crimes.Victim_Status: Businesspeople targeted due to perceived wealth
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Ongoing gang violence in El Salvador
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: State efforts to combat gang activity
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Gang's history of violence and extortion
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – organized gang activity involving threats of death
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: No evidence of individualized targeting beyond profession
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Partially credible but undermined by lack of reporting
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Failure to report incidents reduced reliability

Crimes.Victim_Status: Businesspeople targeted due to perceived wealth
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Pattern of gang violence against business owners
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – part of broader pattern of gang intimidation
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Generalized risk to economically visible individuals
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Based on professional status, not personal characteristics
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Lack of official reporting affected weight

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether failure to report undermines claim of inadequate state protection
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 97(1)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Absence of police reports or formal complaints
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicants must show state unable or unwilling to protect
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Failure to report used to question seriousness of claims
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Presumption of state protection unless rebutted
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of gang violence after unreported incidents
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim rejected due to unrebutted presumption of protection
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Lack of engagement with law enforcement
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Did not attempt to access available legal remedies
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Oral testimony, absence of documentary records

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Part of coercive strategy by gangs to extract money
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: History of similar burglaries by MS
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: No evidence of unique targeting beyond business ownership
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Undermined by lack of official reporting

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Use of threats and violence to enforce payments
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Widespread extortion by MS in the region
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Consistent with general pattern, not individualized
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible but not sufficient for refugee status
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Weakened by non-reporting

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious criminality under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant convicted of fraud over $5000, sentenced to 30 months including pre-sentence custody
Credibility_Assessment: No breach of natural justice found
Decision_Rationale: Pre-sentence custody counts toward sentence under IRPA; no breach of natural justice

Legal_Issue: Whether IAD erred in refusing to reopen appeal
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review after motion to reopen
Evidence_Assessment: Pre-sentence custody credited as part of sentence
Legal_Rule: No appeal if sentence ≥ 2 years; pre-sentence custody included
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged breach of natural justice
Key_Evidence_Considered: 30-month sentence including pre-sentence custody

Legal_Issue: Whether IAD erred in refusing to reopen appeal
Evidence_Assessment: Sentence of 30 months including pre-sentence custody
Legal_Rule: Serious criminality applies if sentence ≥ 2 years
Grounds_for_Claim: Pre-sentence custody should not count
Key_Evidence_Considered: Conviction and sentencing details
Defendant_Response: Argued exclusion of pre-sentence custody from threshold

Application_Facts: Convicted of fraud over $5000 and possession of counterfeit money, total sentence 30 months
Procedural_Issue: Refusal to reopen appeal based on natural justice
Credibility_Assessment: No breach of natural justice found
Decision_Rationale: Sentence exceeds two years including pre-sentence custody; serious criminality applies

Crime_Name: Importing cocaine contrary to Controlled Drugs and Substances Act
Dispute_Type: Deportation appeal based on serious criminality
Legal_Issue: Interpretation of 'punished' in s. 64(2) of IRPA; Charter s. 7 compliance
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 64(2), Controlled Drugs and Substances Act
Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed; Appeal Division lacked jurisdiction
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish grounds for appeal or Charter breach
Legal_Rule: 'Punished' refers to sentence imposed, not time served; no s. 7 liberty interest in deportation for non-citizens
Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of appeal rights under IRPA; alleged Charter s. 7 infringement
Key_Evidence_Considered: Sentencing documents showing three-year sentence
Defendant_Response: Challenged deportation due to lack of appeal rights
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of dismissal; restoration of appeal rights

Crime_Name: Acknowledging an instrument in a false name under Criminal Code
Dispute_Type: Deportation appeal based on serious criminality
Legal_Issue: Interpretation of 'punished' in s. 64(2) of IRPA; Charter s. 7 compliance
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 64(2), Criminal Code
Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed; Appeal Division lacked jurisdiction
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish grounds for appeal or Charter breach
Legal_Rule: 'Punished' refers to sentence imposed, not time served; no s. 7 liberty interest in deportation for non-citizens
Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of appeal rights under IRPA; alleged Charter s. 7 infringement
Key_Evidence_Considered: Sentencing documents showing six-month sentence
Defendant_Response: Challenged dismissal of appeal due to lack of jurisdiction
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of dismissal; restoration of appeal rights

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 74
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed risk of harm upon return to Sierra Leone; PRRA Officer reviewed documentary evidence and found no personal risk linkage
Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure to assess minors' risk, reliance on extrinsic evidence
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence submitted in PRRA application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of linkage between general country conditions and applicants' personal circumstances
Decision_Rationale: No bias found; evidence lacked personal relevance; arguments on minors not raised in submissions

Crimes.Crime_Name: Residency requirement non-compliance under Citizenship Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge erred in assessing residency under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Appeal under subsection 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Travel stamps, tax records, banking transactions, addresses
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate residency compliance
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Contradictions in documentation and implausible claims
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicants must meet one of three criteria: (i) physical presence for three years, (ii) maintaining strong ties while temporarily absent, or (iii) centralizing mode of existence in Canada
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of clarity, logical errors, and improper consideration of irrelevant trips
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Doubts about residency compliance due to inconsistent evidence
Key_Evidence_Considered: Travel stamps
Tax records
Banking transactions
Residential addresses
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Not applicable – applicants were respondents; no response due to service issues
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Redetermination by a different citizenship judge

Crimes.Crime_Name: False or misleading information in citizenship application
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Accuracy and truthfulness of information in citizenship application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge failed to adequately reason the decision on physical presence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Low credibility due to contradictions and omissions
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: False or misleading representations regarding physical presence
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies in travel, tax, banking, and address data
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Statutory appeal under subsection 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Citizenship judge, reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Application_Error: Blending of distinct legal tests for residency instead of applying one method
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Clear, logical, and legally sound reasoning required
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Relevant residency indicators; consideration of trip outside reference period
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Judges must apply one of three established methods for determining residency
Crimes.Application_Factor: Misrepresentation through omission or contradiction in key personal history data
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged inconsistencies suggesting potential falsification or concealment

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in its analysis under section 97(1)(b)(ii) of IRPA regarding personalized risk
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), section 97(1)(b)(ii)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants provided no evidence of continued threat from Los Zetas
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lack of evidence showing ongoing targeting by gang
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Personalized risk due to past threats and extortion by Los Zetas
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Risk found to be generalized due to high crime rates in Mexico
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged error in assessing personalized risk
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified; Board considered available evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Personal risk not faced generally by others in country

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Threats and violence by criminal organization
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Targeted due to perceived wealth and prior extortion
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: No evidence of ongoing pursuit or specific renewed threats
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: History of violent activity by Los Zetas
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Generalized risk due to widespread gang violence
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Initially targeted, but no proof of continued interest
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to establish ongoing personalized risk
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony about past incidents, lack of follow-up threats
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible but limited to past events
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Plausible account but lacking corroboration of current threat

Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: No evidence of sustained targeting after release
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Pattern of kidnappings by Los Zetas
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Generalized risk based on national crime levels
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Not uniquely personal beyond general population exposure
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Previously targeted, but no ongoing evidence
Crimes.Targeted_Individual: Applicant who was kidnapped and released
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Adequate for past event, insufficient for future risk
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony of kidnapping and extortion
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Accepted as credible for past incident
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Truthful recounting but lacks proof of continued threat

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Coercive financial demand by criminal gang
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Use of threats and history of violence by perpetrators
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: No recent contact or demands after initial incident
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Known pattern of extortion by Los Zetas
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Generalized risk due to endemic gang activity
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Not demonstrably individualized beyond societal exposure
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Temporarily targeted based on economic profile
Crimes.Targeted_Individual: Applicants who paid ransom and fled
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient for past harm, inadequate for future risk
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Believable but not indicative of persistent threat
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Consistent narrative but lacks corroborative intelligence

Application_Facts: Applicant was absent for 330 days, falling short by 37 days of the 1,095-day requirement within four years prior to application
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with minimum physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Insufficient reasons provided by Citizenship Judge; failure to clarify which test (physical presence or quality of attachment) was applied
Evidence_Used: Documentation submitted by applicant regarding residency and absences
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of clarity in judicial assessment of evidence; request for additional documentation without explanation
Decision_Outcome: Application initially rejected by Citizenship Judge
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship application refusal
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of application by another Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada within four years preceding application; potential application of 'quality of attachment' test
Decision_Rationale: Judge erred by failing to clearly identify the legal test used and provide adequate reasons for decision
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Commission (via Citizenship Judge), subject to Federal Court review

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possessing cocaine for the purpose of trafficking
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in ID hearing process
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under IRPA s.44(1) and s.44(2)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant did not receive Highlights Report or interview notes but all information was already known
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate breach of procedural fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Not applicable – no challenge to credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness requires disclosure of report and opportunity to make submissions
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: No breach of procedural fairness found
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No request made for additional documents or reasons

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of admissibility and deportation order
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Disclosure of additional documents such as Highlights Report
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Highlights Report and interview notes not disclosed, but not requested
Crimes.Review_Mechanism: Judicial review of CBSA officer's decision and ID order
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Conviction for cocaine trafficking and prior record
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Public safety risk due to drug trafficking conviction
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: None found – no request for additional disclosure

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in referral and reporting process
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of CBSA admissibility report and referral
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: All transmitted information already known to applicant
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness does not require unsolicited internal documents
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No request for interview notes or explanations

Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to rebut presumption of adequate state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants' claims not fully supported by evidence

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequacy of state protection and personalization of risk
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On claimants to show personalized risk and inadequate protection
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicants failed to demonstrate sufficient efforts to seek protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Limited engagement with state authorities beyond initial police contact
Crimes.Legal_Rule: State protection presumed adequate unless clearly rebutted
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of extortion
Steps taken to seek protection
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Recognition as Convention refugee or person in need of protection

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High general risk, low individualized risk
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: No (based on business ownership, not personal targeting)
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Plausible but not substantiated with official reports
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Consistent narrative but lacking corroboration

Violation_Type: Improper application of standard of review
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to threats from Jamaican gangs after refusing involvement in election fraud schemes
Procedural_Issue: RAD failed to independently assess evidence
Overreliance on police report filing as decisive factor
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of independent analysis by RAD
Insufficient consideration of state protection evidence
Credibility_Assessment: RAD did not conduct independent credibility assessment
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by a different RAD panel
Decision_Rationale: RAD unreasonably deferred to RPD instead of conducting independent assessment
Failure to properly analyze state protection evidence

Legal_Issue: Was the Board's rejection based on reasonable credibility findings and procedural fairness?
Credibility_Assessment: Adverse credibility findings due to inconsistencies in testimony and omissions
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to rumored association with a militant group
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of subjective fear demonstrated by post-departure actions

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed domestic violence as persecution in Georgia; inconsistencies in testimony post-2005 affected credibility
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable - claimant was seeking status
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistencies in applicant's testimony affecting credibility
Procedural_Issue: RAD's standard of review on RPD's credibility findings
Jurisdictional_Issue: Jurisdiction of RAD and Federal Court in refugee appeals
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, documentation related to domestic violence claim
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant not credible post-2005; RAD upheld finding under reasonableness standard while conducting independent assessment
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected due to credibility issues
Decision_Rationale: No reviewable error by RAD; RAD properly applied deference where RPD had advantage and conducted independent assessment
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Internal Flight Alternative (IFA)
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision remitted for reassessment
Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Cartagena faced credible threats from Mara 18
Evidence_Type: Country condition reports on El Salvador
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution by non-state actor (gang) in El Salvador
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Viable internal flight alternative must be both factually possible and reasonable considering claimant's circumstances
Application_Error: Failure to properly assess reasonableness of IFA in light of claimant’s vulnerabilities
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard under the Dunsmuir framework
Evidence_Ignored: Lack of familial or community support
High crime and unemployment rates in proposed IFA locations
Application_Factor: Security conditions in proposed IFA locations
Decision_Outcome: Remitted to a differently constituted panel for reconsideration

Application_Facts: PRRA Officer designated under delegation instruments to act under s. 25(1) of IRPA
Claimant_Status: Zolotareva sought permanent residence on humanitarian grounds
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review application filed in Federal Court
Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether PRRA Officer had authority under s. 25(1) of IRPA
Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of PRRA Officer's decision
Decision_Rationale: PRRA Officer had jurisdiction; decision lawful and reasonable

Legal_Issue: Authority of PRRA Officer, natural justice, child's best interests
Credibility_Assessment: No credibility issue found; child’s interests considered
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Child's best interests weighed but not determinative
Application_Error: Alleged breach of natural justice and misapplication of child's best interests
Decision_Outcome: PRRA Officer acted within jurisdiction and decision upheld

Crimes.Crime_Name: Engaging in or instigating the subversion by force of any government
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: PKK uses force against Turkish government
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Armed attacks, supply support to PKK
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Providing supplies, participating in armed attacks
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Admissions by Suleyman supported by context
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Suleyman’s statements deemed credible due to consistency

Crimes.Crime_Name: Subversion by force of any government
Crimes.Application_Facts: Suleyman assisted PKK, present during armed attack
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable – based on actual involvement
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over visa officer decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Admissions accepted as truthful
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of question and reversal of decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Suleyman’s actions aligned with subversion by force
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, affirmed by Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissible on security grounds for being a member of an organization that there are reasonable grounds to believe engages in subversion by force of any government
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Association with PKK poses national security risk
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Assisting PKK, including propaganda and attacks
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible and consistent admissions
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Challenge to interpretation and procedure of inadmissibility

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in an organization engaging in subversion by force.
Crimes.Application_Facts: Suleyman admitted assisting PKK, involved in attacks
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national applying for permanent residence
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of administrative decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Admissions treated as reliable
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Membership and active support meet statutory threshold
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer under IRPA, upheld by Federal Court

Violation_Type: Failure to reconsider humanitarian and compassionate application based on new evidence
Application_Facts: Kurukkal failed to initially provide his late wife's death certificate; submitted it after H&C application was refused
Claimant_Status: Applicant for humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) relief
Procedural_Issue: Invocation of functus officio to deny reconsideration of H&C application
Evidence_Used: Death certificate of late wife (submitted after initial refusal)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Initial failure to submit death certificate
Decision_Outcome: H&C application initially refused due to missing evidence
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remitted for reconsideration with new evidence
Remedy_Sought: Quashing of original decision and referral for re-assessment
Legal_Standard_Applied: Doctrine of functus officio does not bar reconsideration in informal H&C processes
Decision_Rationale: H&C decisions are informal and non-adjudicative, allowing flexibility to consider new evidence even after final decision
Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer responsible for H&C assessment
